content:
Hi Team.

In order to expediate the R&D Light Client process, Chainsafe's Lodestar Light Client can be found here: https://github.com/ChainSafe/lodestar/tree/master/packages/light-client

author: jeremyakatsa
content:
By the looks of it, it seems like they've already barged through Level 1 & 2 based off Jin's classifications and Piper's spotlight so as it appears, there's already a light client implementation in this language:
- Typescript(Lodestar client) {linked above}

Thus, it seems like we'll need light client implementations in these languages:
**- Go**(Prysm client)
**- Rust**(Lighthouse client),
**- Java**(Teku client)
**- Nim**(Nimbus client)
**- C#**(Cortex client)

author: _jmc_.
content: Great - atm Jin is working with Go and I'm on Rust (open door to collaborations as always). One thing I've been wondering though is why we actually need light clients attached to all the full clients - couldnt a light client be agnostic to the full client it queries, since it is just making http requests? I guess it makes sense from a client diversity perspective, and each full client will need to be modified to serve the light client requests anyway so perhaps that is good enough reason.

author: jeremyakatsa
content:
As I understand it, the light clients essentially create ‚Äúsatellite nodes‚Äù within cellphones, laptops and other smaller devices unable to handle the throughput needed to validate full nodes.  Essentially helping to secure the network more.

More info here: https://eth.wiki/concepts/light-client-protocol
